content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is simple, which is ideal for the modes selected for this Clash (Fastest and Shortest). It does involve looping and and conditionals, which makes it around the perfect level for people just beginning to code and wanting to gain experience in time-sensitive coding (for things like interviews and competitive programming events).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun idea, perfect for Fastest and Shortest game modes :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like this idea! It's a good puzzle to show the idea of Euclid's algorithm, and it's easy to code.
Interesting, can't wait to solve it
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
great job user
Intéressant, jai galéré a trouvé la formule mais en fait fallait juste opti!

Fun idea, although the second sentence with "While both numbers are larger than zero (a and b > 0) (a or b <= 0)" is worded confusingly IMO. Two exactly opposite statements in parenthesis confuse matters rather than clarifying them, I think. Maybe just drop them entirely?

It's very great, i like this principe for rapidity or code golf (I Think it's too difficult for reverse mode)

However, few comments :
- Validators 1, 37, 38 & 39 and Test 38 & 39 time out too easily, maybe lower the test value ? (The objective of Clash of Code it's not the optimisation to make it work)
- Specify explicitly when the operation stop (if a or b is lower of zéro) in the explication text. (We can interpret here if stop when a AND b is lower of zero)
I don't think that the wording in the first paragraph "While both numbers..." is good. Does it mean that the test cases will include negative numbers, or will it not
Great puzzle, though maybe a little tough for a clash of code (for my taste).

1. Read two positive integers, a and b, from the user.
2. Create a variable named operations and set it to 0. This variable will keep track of the number of operations performed.
3. Start a loop that continues as long as both a and b are greater than 0.
Inside the loop, compare a and b.
If a is not equal to b, find the larger and smaller numbers, and then:
Increment operations by the integer division of the larger number by the smaller number.
4. Update a to be the difference between the larger and smaller numbers.
Update b to be the smaller number.
If a is equal to b, increment operations by the value of a, and then break out of the loop.
5. Once the loop ends, print the value of operations.
Its a good one, but easy to miss understand it

Pretty clean problem! Reasonably hard for a clash. Only suggestion I have is maybe having a clearer Output explanation; the phrasing "sought" number of operations threw me off a little. That's not a major issue though! Good work :)
Hard but really funny, thanks for your contribution !
Its a Bit Hard But still it is giving me motivation to solve it

validators 1, 38 & 39 plus tests 38 & 39 are not working with some languages (python for ex, time out).

Can't wait to get this one in clash !

Goal section
* Please fix the formatting in the last line.

* Last line: Please change "are" to "is".

Thanks.
Modified.
Simulating multiple (sometimes billions of) operations at once is possible with a simple mathematics trick. There won't be timeout issues if you do so.
Thanks. I changed the wording.

What..? The first sentence mentioned positive numbers already?? Okay even if you missed it there's still the constraints? How can the wording be more clear?
Maybe look through the statement carefully next time.

I think without optimisation this entire problem would be too easy to solve. Also, no offense, but who mentioned that the objective of Clash of Code doesn't include optimisation?
"Clash of Code is a game to improve your coding efficiency by solving short programming problems with other people, at the same time. Players share their solution at the end of a game to help other players improve their coding skills.
WHAT’S THE PURPOSE?
  ⭐ Improve your problem-solving skills
  ⭐ Learn from other people’s code
  ⭐ Practice coding interview questions"
This problem is definitely improving problem-solving skills.

Added a bit more wording for the condition.
Modified. I will still include one of it.
Optimisation within 15 minutes may be an overstretch, but I'll let others decide whether to approve or reject this clash.
Yes abt8601 is correct. This problem isn't intended for you to brute force the problem, but rather think of a mathematical solution.
